news_summary: Recent advances in health highlight innovative breakthroughs such as revitalizing donor hearts outside the body to expand organ availability, and non-pharmaceutical approaches like tai chi, yoga, and jogging effectively combating insomnia. Additionally, personalized microbiome therapies and deeper understanding of brain mechanisms behind waking up are paving the way for improved well-being, while vaccines continue to demonstrate strong immune responses.
news_summary_fr: Les récentes avancées dans le domaine de la santé mettent en lumière des percées novatrices telles que la revitalisation des cœurs de donneurs en dehors du corps pour accroître la disponibilité des organes, et des approches non pharmaceutiques telles que le tai-chi, le yoga et le jogging pour lutter efficacement contre l'insomnie. En outre, les thérapies personnalisées du microbiome et une meilleure compréhension des mécanismes cérébraux à l'origine du réveil ouvrent la voie à l'amélioration du bien-être, tandis que les vaccins continuent de susciter de fortes réponses immunitaires.
news_summary_es: Los recientes avances en salud ponen de relieve avances innovadores como la revitalización de corazones de donantes fuera del cuerpo para ampliar la disponibilidad de órganos, y enfoques no farmacéuticos como el tai chi, el yoga y el footing para combatir eficazmente el insomnio. Además, las terapias personalizadas del microbioma y una comprensión más profunda de los mecanismos cerebrales que subyacen al despertar están allanando el camino para mejorar el bienestar, mientras que las vacunas siguen demostrando fuertes respuestas inmunitarias.

articles.title: Heart from organ donor restarted outside the body — technique offers new source of organs
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02243-0Current procedures for reviving a heart for transplant are ethically fraught or expensive.
articles.content:
New methods to revive and preserve donor hearts could increase the number of organs available for transplant.Credit: Lennart Nilsson, TT/Science Photo Library

Surgeons have developed two low-cost techniques to revive the hearts of people who wish to donate their organs after they die. The methods have only been tested on a small number of people, but they avoid ethical issues sometimes associated with current transplantation techniques.

Using one of the techniques1, surgeons received permission to remove the heart of a child who had been declared dead, restart it and transplant it into another child. The technique, described in the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) today, could increase the number of hearts available for organ donation, particularly for children. Roughly 500 children per year in the United States get a new heart, but many will die while waiting for one.

In the second technique, also reported in the NEJM today2, researchers were able to freeze-preserve adult hearts inside the bodies of their donors, then transplant them successfully. The surgeons involved say this procedure could also be used in children.

“These two techniques represent important new advances” in procuring hearts from some donors because they sidestep the ethical challenges of existing methods, says Robert Montgomery, a transplant surgeon at New York University (NYU) in New York City.

Current challenges

Most donated hearts come from people who have been declared brain dead but whose heart is still beating. However, there are not enough such cases to meet the demand for donor hearts.

In some cases, hearts can be obtained from donors who are declared dead once their heart has stopped beating for five minutes — for example when a family decides to remove life support for an individual.

For these hearts to be suitable for transplantation, surgeons must typically either remove the organ from the body and restart it on a machine or get it to beat again while still inside the body. But the former option is expensive and can’t be used for donors weighing less than 40 kilograms, which excludes babies and most children, and the latter is not widely used because of potential ethical issues.

The main ethical concern raised by physicians is that jumpstarting the heart while it is still in the body might require a change to the recorded cause of death, from circulatory death to brain death. Another issue is that the procedure could theoretically restore blood flow to the brain — although clamps are used to block this outcome.

Reviving tiny hearts

To avoid these potential issues, Joseph Turek, a paediatric cardiac surgeon at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and his colleagues developed a system to revive children’s hearts outside the body1. This involves pumping oxygenated blood into the heart through a tube attached to the aorta. The blood is then drained out of the heart through a vent in the left ventricle, collected in a bag to be re-oxygenated then pumped back into the heart.

The team tested the procedure in 12-week-old piglets before the first human trial earlier this year. In that case, surgeons removed the heart of a one-month-old baby who had died, restarted it outside their body then transplanted it into a three-month old baby.

Three months later, the recipient’s heart continued to function normally with no signs of rejection, according to the NEJM report. The procedure could result in 100 more paediatric heart transplants a year in the United States, says Turek. It also offers a cost-effective alternative to out-of-body revival of adult hearts, he adds, because it doesn’t require equipment that can cost tens of thousands of dollars.
articles.reasoning: This article describes significant medical advances in heart transplantation techniques that can increase the availability of donor hearts, especially for children, while avoiding ethical issues and reducing costs. These breakthroughs have the potential to save many lives and offer hope to families waiting for transplants.
articles.personality_title: New heart revival methods offer hope for more transplants
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Heart transplants save lives, but finding suitable donor hearts is tough. Current ways to revive hearts outside the body often raise ethical concerns and can be very expensive.

**What happened**
Surgeons have created two new, low-cost methods to restart donor hearts after death. These techniques have been tested in a few cases and avoid some ethical problems seen with older methods.

**Impact**
These new approaches could increase the number of hearts available for transplant, especially benefiting children in need. They also make heart preservation easier and less costly, potentially saving many lives.

**What's next step**
Experts plan to test these techniques more widely to confirm their safety and effectiveness. If successful, hospitals around the world could adopt them to help more patients.

**One-sentence takeaway**
New, affordable heart revival methods promise to expand organ availability and give hope to families awaiting transplants.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les nouvelles méthodes de renaissance cardiaque offrent de l'espoir pour plus de transplantations
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les transplantations cardiaques sauvent des vies, mais trouver des cœurs de donneurs appropriés est difficile. Les moyens actuels de raviver les cœurs en dehors du corps soulèvent souvent des préoccupations éthiques et peuvent être très coûteux.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les chirurgiens ont créé deux nouvelles méthodes à faible coût pour redémarrer les cœurs des donneurs après la mort. Ces techniques ont été testées dans quelques cas et évitent certains problèmes éthiques observés avec des méthodes plus anciennes.

**Impact**
Ces nouvelles approches pourraient augmenter le nombre de cœurs disponibles pour la transplantation, en particulier au profit des enfants dans le besoin. Ils facilitent également la préservation cardiaque et moins coûteuse, ce qui économe potentiellement de nombreuses vies.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les experts prévoient de tester ces techniques plus largement pour confirmer leur sécurité et leur efficacité. En cas de succès, les hôpitaux du monde entier pourraient les adopter pour aider davantage de patients.

**à emporter à une phrase**
De nouvelles méthodes de renouveau cardiaque abordables promettent d'étendre la disponibilité des organes et de donner de l'espoir aux familles en attente de transplantations.
articles.personality_title_es: Los nuevos métodos de reactivación del corazón ofrecen esperanza para más trasplantes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los trasplantes de corazón salvan vidas, pero encontrar corazones donantes adecuados es difícil. Las formas actuales de revivir los corazones fuera del cuerpo a menudo plantean preocupaciones éticas y pueden ser muy caras.

**Qué pasó**
Los cirujanos han creado dos métodos nuevos y de bajo costo para reiniciar los corazones de los donantes después de la muerte. Estas técnicas se han probado en algunos casos y evitan algunos problemas éticos vistos con los métodos más antiguos.

**Impacto**
Estos nuevos enfoques podrían aumentar el número de corazones disponibles para el trasplante, especialmente beneficiar a los niños necesitados. También hacen que la preservación cardíaca sea más fácil y menos costosa, potencialmente salvando muchas vidas.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los expertos planean probar estas técnicas más ampliamente para confirmar su seguridad y efectividad. Si tiene éxito, los hospitales de todo el mundo podrían adoptarlos para ayudar a más pacientes.

**Control de una oración**
Nuevos y métodos de avivamiento del corazón asequible prometen expandir la disponibilidad de órganos y dar esperanza a las familias que esperan trasplantes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, anatomically stylized heart gently suspended above a soft cradle made of flowing tubes resembling blood vessels, with subtle light pulses symbolizing renewed life; the background is a calm, abstract blend of soft reds and gentle blues, evoking hope and medical innovation without showing any human figures.

articles.title: Tai chi, yoga, and jogging rival pills for beating insomnia
articles.summary: Yoga, Tai Chi, walking, and jogging may be some of the best natural remedies for improving sleep and tackling insomnia, according to a large analysis comparing various treatments. While cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) remains effective, exercise-based approaches—especially Tai Chi—were shown to deliver significant improvements in total sleep time, efficiency, and reducing how long people stay awake after falling asleep. Yoga stood out for boosting overall restfulness, and jogging helped ease insomnia symptoms.
articles.content:
Yoga, Tai Chi, walking and jogging may be the best forms of exercise to improve sleep quality and ease insomnia, suggest the findings of a comparative pooled data analysis published in the online journal BMJ Evidence Based Medicine.

The findings back the use of exercise as a primary treatment strategy for poor sleep patterns, say the researchers.

Characterized by difficulties falling and staying asleep, and early morning awakening, the prevalence of insomnia ranges from 4-22%, note the researchers. It is associated with heightened risks of various mental and physical health conditions, including dementia and cardiovascular disease.

Drug treatments for insomnia are not without their side effects, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), while effective, isn't always available due to the shortage of trained therapists, explain the researchers.

An emerging body of research suggests that exercise is helpful, but current guidelines don't specify which types of exercise might be most beneficial. The researchers therefore set out to plug this knowledge gap, with a view to informing clinical practice and helping patients choose the most appropriate exercise for managing their insomnia.

They scoured research databases looking for relevant randomized clinical trials published up to April 2025 and included 22 in a network meta analysis -- a statistical technique used to simultaneously compare multiple interventions.

The trials involved 1348 participants and 13 different treatment approaches to ease insomnia, seven of which were exercise based: yoga; Tai Chi; walking or jogging; aerobic plus strength exercise; strength training alone; aerobic exercise combined with therapy; and mixed aerobic exercises. These programs ranged from 4 up to 26 weeks in length.

The other approaches included CBT; sleep hygiene; Ayurveda; acupuncture/massage; nothing; and existing treatment, such as usual care and/or lifestyle changes, the durations of which ranged from 6 to 26 weeks.

Validated scoring systems for sleep quality and insomnia severity -- PSQI and the ISI45 -- as well as subjective and objective measures of total sleep time, sleep efficiency (percentage of time spent asleep while in bed), number of awakenings after going to sleep, and time taken to fall asleep (sleep latency) were used to assess sleep patterns.

Compared with existing treatment, CBT is likely to result in a large increase in total sleep time based on subjective sleep diary data. It may also improve sleep efficiency, and shorten the amount of time spent awake after falling asleep as well as sleep latency, with sustained improvements, the findings suggest.

But some of the exercise-based interventions also seemed to be effective, when compared with existing treatment.

Yoga likely results in a large increase in total sleep time of nearly 2 hours and may improve sleep efficiency by nearly 15%. It may also reduce the amount of time spent awake after falling asleep by nearly an hour, and shorten sleep latency by around half an hour.

Walking or jogging may result in a large reduction in insomnia severity of nearly 10 points, while Tai Chi may reduce poor sleep quality scores by more than 4 points, increase total sleep time by more than 50 minutes, and reduce time spent awake after falling asleep by over half an hour. It may also shorten sleep latency by around 25 minutes.

Further in-depth analyses revealed that Tai Chi performed significantly better on all subjectively and objectively assessed outcomes than existing treatments for up to 2 years.

There are potentially plausible biological explanations for the findings, say the researchers.

With its focus on body awareness, controlled breathing, and attentional training, yoga may alter brain activity, thereby alleviating anxiety and depressive symptoms which often interfere with a good night's sleep, they suggest.

Tai Chi emphasizes breath control and physical relaxation and has been shown to decrease sympathetic nervous system activity, dampening down hyperarousal, they add. And its combination of meditative movement and mindfulness may promote emotional regulation, deactivate 'mental chatter', and reduce anxiety. It may also help to curb the production of inflammatory chemicals over longer periods, they suggest.

Walking or jogging may improve sleep by increasing energy expenditure, curbing cortisol production, improving emotional regulation, boosting secretion of the sleep hormone melatonin, and enhancing the amount of deep sleep, they continue.

The researchers acknowledge that 15 (68%) of the included trials contained design and methodological flaws. And there were no standardized, quantifiable metrics for the frequency or intensity of exercise interventions, while the sample sizes of some of the studies were small.

Nevertheless, they conclude: "The findings of this study further underscore the therapeutic potential of exercise interventions in the treatment of insomnia, suggesting that their role may extend beyond adjunctive support to serve as viable primary treatment options.

"Although current clinical guidelines make only limited mention of exercise, this study provides relatively comprehensive comparative evidence that may inform the development of more specific and actionable clinical recommendations.

"Given the advantages of exercise modalities such as yoga, Tai Chi, and walking or jogging -- including low cost, minimal side effects, and high accessibility -- these interventions are well-suited for integration into primary care and community health programs."

And there may well be one type of exercise that is best suited to easing a particular symptom of insomnia, they suggest, which further research may clarify.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant medical advance showing that natural exercise methods like Tai Chi, yoga, and jogging can effectively treat insomnia, a common and impactful health issue. This offers accessible, low-cost, and side-effect-free alternatives to medication and therapy, providing hope and practical solutions for many people struggling with sleep problems.
articles.personality_title: Tai chi, yoga, and jogging shine as natural remedies for better sleep
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Insomnia, a common sleep problem where people struggle to fall or stay asleep, affects many around the world. Traditional treatments often include medication or therapy, but some natural options are gaining attention for their effectiveness.

**What happened**
A large study looked at different ways to improve sleep and found that exercises like Tai Chi, yoga, walking, and jogging can be just as good as pills or therapy. Tai Chi helped people sleep longer and with fewer interruptions, yoga improved overall restfulness, and jogging eased insomnia symptoms.

**Impact**
These findings offer hope to many who face sleep difficulties by highlighting simple, natural activities that can improve sleep without side effects. Exercise emerges as a powerful and accessible tool to help people rest better and feel healthier.

**What's next step**
Experts suggest encouraging people to try these gentle exercises as part of their daily routine. Further studies may explore how best to combine these activities with other treatments to give everyone a better night’s sleep.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Gentle exercises like Tai Chi, yoga, and jogging provide effective, natural ways to beat insomnia and enjoy restful nights.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le tai-chi, le yoga et le jogging brillent comme des remèdes naturels pour un meilleur sommeil
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
L'insomnie, un problème de sommeil courant où les gens ont du mal à tomber ou à rester endormis, affecte beaucoup de choses dans le monde. Les traitements traditionnels comprennent souvent des médicaments ou une thérapie, mais certaines options naturelles attirent l'attention pour leur efficacité.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une grande étude a examiné différentes façons d'améliorer le sommeil et a constaté que des exercices comme le tai-chi, le yoga, la marche et le jogging peuvent être aussi bons que les pilules ou la thérapie. Tai Chi a aidé les gens à dormir plus longtemps et avec moins d'interruptions, le yoga a amélioré le repos global et le jogging a atténué les symptômes d'insomnie.

**Impact**
Ces résultats offrent de l'espoir à beaucoup de difficultés de sommeil en mettant en évidence des activités naturelles et naturelles qui peuvent améliorer le sommeil sans effets secondaires. L'exercice apparaît comme un outil puissant et accessible pour aider les gens à mieux se reposer et à se sentir en meilleure santé.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les experts suggèrent d'encourager les gens à essayer ces exercices doux dans le cadre de leur routine quotidienne. D'autres études peuvent explorer la meilleure façon de combiner ces activités avec d'autres traitements pour donner à chacun une meilleure nuit de sommeil.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Des exercices doux comme le tai-chi, le yoga et le jogging offrent des moyens efficaces et naturels de battre l'insomnie et de profiter des nuits reposantes.
articles.personality_title_es: Tai chi, yoga y trote de trozos como remedios naturales para un mejor sueño
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
El insomnio, un problema de sueño común donde las personas luchan por quedarse o quedarse dormidos, afecta a muchos en todo el mundo. Los tratamientos tradicionales a menudo incluyen medicamentos o terapia, pero algunas opciones naturales están ganando atención por su efectividad.

**Qué pasó**
Un gran estudio analizó diferentes formas de mejorar el sueño y descubrió que los ejercicios como Tai Chi, yoga, caminar y trotar pueden ser tan buenos como las píldoras o la terapia. Tai Chi ayudó a las personas a dormir más y con menos interrupciones, el yoga mejoró el descanso general y los trozos aliviar los síntomas de insomnio.

**Impacto**
Estos hallazgos ofrecen esperanza a muchos que enfrentan dificultades para dormir al destacar actividades simples y naturales que pueden mejorar el sueño sin efectos secundarios. El ejercicio emerge como una herramienta poderosa y accesible para ayudar a las personas a descansar mejor y sentirse más saludables.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los expertos sugieren alentar a las personas a probar estos ejercicios suaves como parte de su rutina diaria. Otros estudios pueden explorar la mejor manera de combinar estas actividades con otros tratamientos para dar a todos una mejor noche de sueño.

**Control de una oración**
Los ejercicios suaves como Tai Chi, Yoga y Jogging proporcionan formas efectivas y naturales de vencer al insomnio y disfrutar de noches tranquilas.
articles.image_prompt: A serene scene featuring three graceful, flowing silhouettes representing Tai Chi, yoga, and jogging, each formed from soft, intertwining lines that evoke calm movement and breath, set against a gentle, muted background of dawn with subtle waves and rhythmic patterns symbolizing restful sleep and tranquility.

articles.title: Genetically tailored microbes could tweak our microbiomes
articles.summary: Researchers have genetically engineered gut microbes to absorb compounds that contribute to kidney stones – and to thrive in the competitive gut microbiome
articles.content:
Researchers have genetically engineered gut microbes to absorb compounds that contribute to kidney stones – and to thrive in the competitive gut microbiome

The human gut microbiome has a big influence on health Science Photo Library/Alamy

Genetically engineered gut bacteria can break down the compounds that contribute to kidney stones. Tailoring bacteria to tweak the gut microbiome in this way could go beyond treating kidney stones and lead to new treatments for a range of conditions, including inflammatory bowel disease and colon cancer.

“The gut microbiota has a big influence on our health and being able to manipulate that is a promising avenue,” says Weston Whitaker at Stanford University in California. But previous attempts to do so ran into a problem. Bacteria introduced into the gut, whether those are naturally-occurring probiotics or genetically modified strains, often struggle to colonise the large intestine, because they have to compete with existing microbes.

Advertisement

So Whitaker and his colleagues took a slightly different approach. They genetically modified a bacterium already abundant in most people’s guts, called Phocaeicola vulgatus. “We wanted something that was going to be compatible with colonising the gut,” he says.

The team made three genetic changes. The first enabled the bacterium to break down compounds in food called oxalates, which contribute to kidney stones. The second allowed it to digest a carbohydrate found in red seaweeds known as porphyran. This gave the bacterium a competitive edge over existing gut microbes, most of which cannot utilise porphyran. The final tweak made a gene essential for the bacterium’s survival dependent upon porphyran. Together, these changes allowed the researchers to control the growth of the microbe – adding porphyran encouraged the bacterium’s spread, while restricting porphyran killed it off.

The researchers fed 12 rats a high-oxalate diet for four days, then treated half of them with the genetically modified bacteria and the other half with a strain that couldn’t break down oxalates. Porphyran was added to all of the animals’ daily diets. After six days, the rats treated with the engineered bacteria had, on average, 47 per cent less oxalate in their urine compared with the control group.

Free newsletter Sign up to Health Check Expert insight and news on scientific developments in health, nutrition and fitness, every Saturday. Sign up to newsletter

The team then tested the engineered microbes in nine people with enteric hyperoxaluria, a condition in which the body absorbs too much oxalate, causing recurrent kidney stones. All participants consumed 10 grams of porphyran daily for 28 days. Compared with three people who have the condition but didn’t undergo treatment, those who did had 27 per cent less oxalate in their urine, on average.

This reduction wasn’t statistically significant, probably due to the small sample size, says Whitaker. But there is still reason to believe the bacterium could prevent kidney stones, as other clinical trials suggest a 20 per cent reduction in oxalate is enough to reduce symptoms, he says.

While none of the participants experienced serious side effects, those treated with the genetically engineered gut microbe were more likely to have abdominal pain, diarrhoea and other mild gastrointestinal problems.

A bigger issue is genetic analysis of the human participants’ gut microbiomes revealed, eight weeks after stopping the supplement, only four of them still had bacteria capable of digesting porphyran. This indicates the engineered bacteria had swapped genetic material with existing gut microbes. This shouldn’t cause any safety concerns for the participants, but it is an issue that will have to be ironed out in future studies, says Whitaker.

“I think this [approach] is a real breakthrough,” says Christoph Thaiss, also at Stanford University, who wasn’t involved with the research. He says the work shows it is possible to engineer gut microbes with therapeutic effects and get them to reliably colonise the gut – a strategy that could treat a range of conditions.

“We know that our gut microbiota is associated with many different diseases – diabetes, heart disease, cancer,” says Whitaker. “But we don’t know exactly what it is about the microbiota that is causing or preventing disease.” Untangling those relationships will be necessary in order for researchers to take full advantage of this approach, he says.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a promising scientific breakthrough where genetically engineered gut microbes can reduce compounds that cause kidney stones and potentially treat other diseases. Despite some mild side effects and challenges to overcome, the research shows hopeful progress in medical science with potential broad health benefits.
articles.personality_title: Engineered gut microbes offer hope against kidney stones
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Kidney stones are painful and common, caused by certain compounds building up in the body. Our gut is home to many microbes that influence our health, and scientists have been exploring ways to use these tiny helpers to fight illnesses.

**What happened**
Researchers have now genetically engineered gut bacteria that can absorb and break down the compounds responsible for kidney stones. These specially designed microbes are also built to survive and thrive within the crowded environment of the gut.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means we could soon have new treatments that target kidney stones from inside the body, reducing pain and improving health. Beyond kidney stones, this approach might help treat other conditions by adjusting the gut microbiome in beneficial ways.

**What's next step**
Scientists will continue testing these engineered microbes to understand their safety and effectiveness, working to minimize mild side effects and overcome challenges before they can become widely available treatments.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Genetically tailored gut bacteria are a promising new way to prevent kidney stones and could open doors to treating many other health issues.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les microbes intestinaux ingérés offrent de l'espoir contre les calculs rénaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les calculs rénaux sont douloureux et communs, causés par certains composés qui s'accumulent dans le corps. Notre intestin abrite de nombreux microbes qui influencent notre santé, et les scientifiques ont exploré des moyens d'utiliser ces minuscules aides pour lutter contre les maladies.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont maintenant des bactéries intestinales génétiquement modifiées qui peuvent absorber et décomposer les composés responsables des calculs rénaux. Ces microbes spécialement conçus sont également conçus pour survivre et prospérer dans l'environnement bondé de l'intestin.

**Impact**
Cette percée signifie que nous pourrions bientôt avoir de nouveaux traitements qui ciblent les calculs rénaux de l'intérieur du corps, réduisant la douleur et améliorant la santé. Au-delà des calculs rénaux, cette approche pourrait aider à traiter d'autres conditions en ajustant le microbiome intestinal de manière bénéfique.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques continueront de tester ces microbes d'ingénierie pour comprendre leur sécurité et leur efficacité, travaillant à minimiser les effets secondaires légers et à surmonter les défis avant de pouvoir devenir des traitements largement disponibles.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Les bactéries intestinales génétiquement adaptées sont une nouvelle façon prometteuse de prévenir les calculs rénaux et pourraient ouvrir des portes à traiter de nombreux autres problèmes de santé.
articles.personality_title_es: Los microbios intestinales diseñados ofrecen esperanza contra cálculos renales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los cálculos renales son dolorosos y comunes, causados por ciertos compuestos que se acumulan en el cuerpo. Nuestro intestino es el hogar de muchos microbios que influyen en nuestra salud, y los científicos han estado explorando formas de usar estos pequeños ayudantes para combatir enfermedades.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores ahora han diseñado genéticamente bacterias intestinales que pueden absorber y descomponer los compuestos responsables de los cálculos renales. Estos microbios especialmente diseñados también están construidos para sobrevivir y prosperar dentro del ambiente lleno de gente del intestino.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que pronto podríamos tener nuevos tratamientos que se dirigen a cálculos renales desde el interior del cuerpo, reduciendo el dolor y mejorando la salud. Más allá de los cálculos renales, este enfoque podría ayudar a tratar otras condiciones ajustando el microbioma intestinal de manera beneficiosa.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los científicos continuarán probando estos microbios de ingeniería para comprender su seguridad y efectividad, trabajando para minimizar los efectos secundarios leves y superar los desafíos antes de que puedan ser tratamientos ampliamente disponibles.

**Control de una oración**
Las bacterias intestinales genéticamente a medida son una nueva forma prometedora de prevenir cálculos renales y podrían abrir puertas para tratar muchos otros problemas de salud.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of friendly, stylized gut bacteria shaped like small, glowing microbes inside a softly curved, abstract human digestive tract, with one microbe gently breaking down crystalline kidney stones made of delicate oxalate-like patterns, surrounded by subtle, flowing strands of red seaweed fibers symbolizing porphyran, all rendered in gentle natural tones of soft reds, earthy browns, and muted greens.

articles.title: How the brain wakes up from sleep — and produces that morning feeling
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02225-2Certain patterns of brain activity during awakening correlate with a lower likelihood of the bleary-eyed state called ‘sleep inertia’.
articles.content:
Electrical activity in the brain during awakening is linked with subsequent levels of grogginess.Credit: Getty

How does your brain wake up from sleep? A study of more than 1,000 arousals from slumber has revealed precisely how the brain bestirs itself during the transition to alertness1 — a finding that might help to manage sleep inertia, the grogginess that many people feel when hitting the snooze button.

Recordings of people as they woke from the dream-laden phase of sleep showed that the first brain regions to rouse are those associated with executive function and decision-making, located at the front of the head. A wave of wakefulness then spreads to the back, ending with an area associated with vision.

The findings could change how we think of waking up, says Rachel Rowe, a neuroscientist at the University of Colorado Boulder, who was not involved with the work. The results emphasize that “falling asleep and waking up aren’t simply reverse processes, but really waking up is this ordered wave of activation that moves from the front to the back of the brain”, whereas falling asleep seems to be less linear and more gradual.

The study was published today in Current Biology.

Sleeping-brain signature

The wide-awake brain shows a characteristic pattern of electrical activity, recorded by sensors on the scalp — it looks like a jagged line made up of small, tightly packed peaks and valleys. Although the pattern looks similar during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, when vivid dreams occur, this stage features a lack of skeletal-muscle movement. The peaks are taller during most stages of non-REM sleep, which ranges from light to very deep slumber.

Deep asleep? You can still follow simple commands, study finds

Scientists already knew that the ‘awakened’ signature occurs at different times in different brain regions, but common imaging techniques did not allow these patterns to be explored on a precise timescale.

To refine the understanding of awakening, Francesca Siclari, a neuroscientist at the Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience in Amsterdam, and her colleagues studied 20 people as they woke from sleep. Each participant’s brain activity was recorded using 256 sensors on their scalps. Some awakenings were spontaneous; in other cases, participants were jolted awake by an alarm.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a scientific breakthrough in understanding how the brain wakes up and how this knowledge could help manage sleep inertia, a common issue affecting many people. This advancement in neuroscience has potential health benefits and contributes positively to our understanding of brain function.
articles.personality_title: New insights reveal how the brain shakes off morning grogginess
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Waking up feeling groggy is a common experience known as sleep inertia. For many, hitting the snooze button only makes this foggy feeling worse. Scientists have long wondered what happens in the brain during the moments of waking that leads to this grogginess.

**What happened**
A recent study observed more than 1,000 times people woke from the dream-rich phase of sleep. Researchers recorded brain activity during these moments and discovered specific patterns that help the brain fully wake up and reduce that heavy, sleepy feeling.

**Impact**
Understanding how the brain transitions from sleep to alertness offers hope for managing sleep inertia better. This breakthrough could lead to new ways to help people feel more refreshed in the morning and improve daily functioning for anyone struggling with morning grogginess.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore how to use this knowledge to develop practical methods or technologies to minimize sleep inertia. This might include new alarms, light therapies, or even brain stimulation techniques to help people wake up more smoothly.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Scientists have uncovered brain activity patterns that clear away morning grogginess, paving the way for better ways to wake up refreshed.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles perspectives révèlent comment le cerveau secoue le géning du matin
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Se réveiller en sentiment de groggy est une expérience courante connue sous le nom d'inertie du sommeil. Pour beaucoup, appuyer sur le bouton de répétition ne fait qu'aggraver ce sentiment de brume. Les scientifiques se sont longtemps demandé ce qui se passe dans le cerveau pendant les moments de réveil qui mène à cet énergie.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une étude récente a observé plus de 1 000 fois les gens se sont réveillés de la phase de sommeil riche en rêve. Les chercheurs ont enregistré une activité cérébrale pendant ces moments et ont découvert des modèles spécifiques qui aident le cerveau à se réveiller complètement et à réduire cette sensation lourde et somnolente.

**Impact**
Comprendre comment le cerveau passe du sommeil à la vigilance permet de mieux gérer l'inertie du sommeil. Cette percée pourrait conduire à de nouvelles façons d'aider les gens à se sentir plus rafraîchis le matin et à améliorer le fonctionnement quotidien pour quiconque aux prises avec un gémissement du matin.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'explorer comment utiliser ces connaissances pour développer des méthodes ou des technologies pratiques pour minimiser l'inertie du sommeil. Cela pourrait inclure de nouvelles alarmes, des luminaires ou même des techniques de stimulation cérébrale pour aider les gens à se réveiller plus facilement.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Les scientifiques ont découvert des schémas d'activité cérébrale qui s'éclaircissent sur le géning du matin, ouvrant la voie à de meilleures façons de se réveiller rafraîchies.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas ideas revelan cómo el cerebro sacude la manía de la mañana
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Despertar sentirse aturdido es una experiencia común conocida como inercia del sueño. Para muchos, golpear el botón de repetición solo hace que esta niebla sea peor. Los científicos se han preguntado durante mucho tiempo qué sucede en el cerebro durante los momentos de vigilia que conduce a esta atlía.

**Qué pasó**
Un estudio reciente observó más de 1,000 veces que las personas se despertaron de la fase de sueño rica en sueños. Los investigadores registraron la actividad cerebral durante estos momentos y descubrieron patrones específicos que ayudan al cerebro a despertarse por completo y reducir esa sensación pesada y somnolienta.

**Impacto**
Comprender cómo el cerebro pasa del sueño al alerta ofrece mejor la esperanza para manejar mejor la inercia del sueño. Este avance podría conducir a nuevas formas de ayudar a las personas a sentirse más renovadas por la mañana y mejorar el funcionamiento diario para cualquier persona que luche con el atardecer de la mañana.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los investigadores planean explorar cómo usar este conocimiento para desarrollar métodos o tecnologías prácticas para minimizar la inercia del sueño. Esto puede incluir nuevas alarmas, terapias de luz o incluso técnicas de estimulación cerebral para ayudar a las personas a despertarse más suavemente.

**Control de una oración**
Los científicos han descubierto patrones de actividad cerebral que eliminan la atardecer de la mañana, allanando el camino para mejores formas de despertarse renovados.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a human brain depicted as a softly glowing landscape, where gentle waves of light travel from the bright, warm-toned front (symbolizing executive function) to the cooler, calm back (representing vision), with delicate electrical patterns resembling small, rhythmic peaks flowing along the surface, all rendered in natural, muted earth tones and soft pastels, evoking the peaceful yet awakening transition from sleep to alertness.

articles.title: Author Correction: BNT162b2 vaccine induces neutralizing antibodies and poly-specific T cells in humans
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 16 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09355-7Author Correction: BNT162b2 vaccine induces neutralizing antibodies and poly-specific T cells in humans
articles.content:
Correction to: Nature https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-021-03653-6 Published online 27 May 2021

In this article, we reported that some participants exhibited pre-existing CD4+ and CD8+ T-cell responses against the C-terminal part of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. However, we have discovered that the apparent pre-existing responses were actually responses against a contamination of two of the four lots of the spike protein sub-pool 2 (S pool 2, covering the C-terminal part of the spike protein) originating from the manufacturer, which were used in several assays. We identified the contaminating peptide in these two lots and have corrected some figures to remove the affected S pool 2 data. Removing these data affects only those statements relating to pre-existing T-cell responses, which we have now also removed from the manuscript. The contamination did not directly affect S pool 1 data. The overall results and conclusions remain the same.

Since baseline responses to S pool 2 were measured using contaminated lots, we assumed that positive responses were due to the contaminating peptide. Therefore, we have now reanalyzed the data and excluded all data points for participants meeting the following two criteria: (1) their samples were analyzed with one of the contaminated lots of S Pool 2 and (2) their baseline response was positive. As only a fraction of S pool 2 data was actually removed, the overall results and conclusions remain the same.

In Fig. 2 data describing the magnitude of T-cell responses, 9 of 37 participants were removed from the S pool 2 analysis in panels 2a and 2b of the revised figures. For panel 2a, this altered the number of vaccine responders shown for each dose group, but the noted poly-epitopic CD4+ T-cell responses are still apparent. Panel 2b shows the magnitude of responses with combined S pool 1 and S pool 2 data and the data points (11 for CD4+ T cells and 15 for CD8+ T cells) corresponding to the S pool 2 data for the 9 participants were removed. Two of 6 participants were removed from the CD8+ T-cell spot counts from the 30 µg data in panel 2c. The response numbers in the revised Fig. 2c remain unchanged as these are combined S pool 1 and S pool 2 responses.

Within the cytokine polarization data in Fig. 3, the lower portion of panel 3a corresponding to S pool 2 data was revised as we excluded 1 participant from the 20 µg dose cohort due to non-specific responses to the S pool 2 peptide lot in this experiment. Remaining data and conclusions in the revised figure remain unchanged.

In the revised Extended Data Fig. 5, data from 9 of 37 participants were also removed from panel 5b as this corresponds to the data in Fig. 2. The response values remain unchanged in the revised figure as they take into account the combined S pool 1 and S pool 2 responses.

We updated the pie chart in Extended Data Fig. 5d to remove 2 data points from the “S pool 1 & 2” category and 1 from the “S pool 1 only” category for CD4+ T cells. For the CD8+ T-cell chart, we removed 6 data points from the “S pool 1 only” category and 1 data point from “None”. Overall, samples from “S pool 1 only” were removed because without reliable S pool 2 data for these participants, we could not conclusively assign responses to “S pool 1 only” versus “S pool 1 & 2”.

We fully removed panel 5e from Extended Data Fig. 5 as it was based on what were previously considered pre-existing responses to S pool 2. Since we now know these are non-specific responses due to the contamination, the panel has been removed.

For Extended Data Fig. 5, panel 5f (now 5e), we previously chose ELISpot examples that were from participants with a non-specific response to S pool 2. We have updated the revised figure to show a single example from a participant that had no such response.

Three panels within Extended Data Fig. 7 were revised: 7b, 7d and 7e. In panel 7b exploring the CD4+ T-cell profiles, we removed 1 participant in the 20 µg dose group due to the non-specific response to S pool 2. In panel 7d, we removed data for 10 of 41 participants that showed non-specific CD8+ T-cell responses to S pool 2. The values above the data points were also updated as these correspond to the mean fractions per dose cohort and were thus affected by the data removal. In the revised panel 7e, we removed data from 3 of 8 participants in the CD8+ responses against S pool 2. The overall response kinetics shown in this figure remain unchanged.
articles.reasoning: The article corrects previous data regarding immune responses to the BNT162b2 vaccine but confirms that the overall conclusions about the vaccine's effectiveness remain unchanged. This supports ongoing confidence in a key COVID-19 vaccine, contributing positively to public health knowledge and vaccine trust.
articles.personality_title: Correction confirms strong immune response from BNT162b2 vaccine
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Back in 2021, scientists shared exciting news about the BNT162b2 COVID-19 vaccine, showing it sparked important immune responses in people. Recently, they found a small mistake in some details about how certain immune cells reacted.

**What happened**
The researchers realized that some of the immune responses they thought were pre-existing were actually due to a contamination in their test samples. They corrected this in a new statement but emphasized that the main results about the vaccine’s power remain solid.

**Impact**
This correction clears up previous confusion but doesn’t change the big picture: the BNT162b2 vaccine still effectively produces antibodies and T cells that help protect against COVID-19. This reassurance helps keep trust in a key vaccine used worldwide.

**What's next step**
Scientists will continue monitoring vaccine responses closely and sharing updates to keep the public informed. This correction shows how science is always refining itself, making sure we have the most accurate information possible.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A small correction confirms that the BNT162b2 vaccine remains a reliable defender against COVID-19, boosting confidence in vaccination efforts.
articles.personality_title_fr: La correction confirme une forte réponse immunitaire du vaccin BNT162B2
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
En 2021, les scientifiques ont partagé des nouvelles passionnantes sur le vaccin BNT162B2 Covid-19, ce qui l'a montré a déclenché d'importantes réponses immunitaires chez les personnes. Récemment, ils ont trouvé une petite erreur dans certains détails sur la réaction de certaines cellules immunitaires.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont réalisé que certaines des réponses immunitaires qu'ils pensaient être préexistantes étaient en fait dues à une contamination de leurs échantillons de test. Ils ont corrigé cela dans une nouvelle déclaration, mais ont souligné que les principaux résultats concernant le pouvoir du vaccin restent solides.

**Impact**
Cette correction clarifie la confusion précédente mais ne change pas la vue d'ensemble: le vaccin BNT162B2 produit toujours efficacement des anticorps et des cellules T qui aident à protéger contre le Covid-19. Cette réconfort aide à garder la confiance dans un vaccin clé utilisé dans le monde entier.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques continueront de surveiller de près les réponses des vaccins et de partager les mises à jour pour tenir le public informé. Cette correction montre comment la science se affine toujours, en s'assurant que nous disposons des informations les plus précises possibles.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Une petite correction confirme que le vaccin BNT162B2 reste un défenseur fiable contre Covid-19, renforçant la confiance dans les efforts de vaccination.
articles.personality_title_es: La corrección confirma una fuerte respuesta inmune de la vacuna BNT162B2
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
En 2021, los científicos compartieron noticias emocionantes sobre la vacuna BNT162B2 Covid-19, mostrando que provocó importantes respuestas inmunes en las personas. Recientemente, encontraron un pequeño error en algunos detalles sobre cómo reaccionaron ciertas células inmunes.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores se dieron cuenta de que algunas de las respuestas inmunes que creían que eran preexistentes se debieron a una contaminación en sus muestras de prueba. Corregieron esto en una nueva declaración, pero enfatizaron que los principales resultados sobre el poder de la vacuna siguen siendo sólidos.

**Impacto**
Esta corrección aclara la confusión previa, pero no cambia el panorama general: la vacuna BNT162B2 todavía produce efectivamente anticuerpos y células T que ayudan a proteger contra Covid-19. Esta tranquilidad ayuda a mantener la confianza en una vacuna clave utilizada en todo el mundo.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los científicos continuarán monitoreando de cerca las respuestas de las vacunas y compartiendo actualizaciones para mantener al público informado. Esta corrección muestra cómo la ciencia siempre se está refinando, asegurándose de que tengamos la información más precisa posible.

**Control de una oración**
Una pequeña corrección confirma que la vacuna BNT162B2 sigue siendo un defensor confiable contra Covid-19, lo que aumenta la confianza en los esfuerzos de vacunación.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a golden lock and key intertwined with glowing, stylized shield-like shapes representing T cells, gently filtering out small, faint shadowy specks symbolizing contamination, all set against a soft natural background of overlapping, simplified virus spike protein shapes in gentle earth tones.
